body:
I have learned the example.
But,I want to use C++ API or C API.
Thanks for your help.

here is a c++ example to get the output 

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/cpp/image-classification

you can use MXPredCreatePartialOut added on PR #1060 instead of MXPredCreate to get the output of any internal layers

This is a pleasant surprise!
Thank you very much!
@piiswrong I think what tianqi considered is to keep the contribution history. I wonder If we transfer it's ownership later to dmlc, will all these commit history also be transferred?
Thanks a lot！
What is your results on cifar10? If it is the same as the paper, we can merge in, otherwise we had better to find the reasons to avoid confusion to others.
There is a Torch 7 implementation which can be ported to MXNet. https://github.com/fchollet/keras/issues/383#issuecomment-166850153

I think we have the same environment variable and it works on my machine.

```
~$ echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH
/usr/local/cuda-7.5/lib64
```

Have you ever tried to compile and run any cuda examples?
The result in https://github.com/shuokay/mxnet/commit/cd28e159d2509bf8799ad36a3219ecd5ac1b0a4f is "train accuracy around 82.7% and test accuracy 75.6%".

Maybe we should try to speed up Travis tests instead. For example:
1. only run Scala tests when there are files changed in Scala directory. 
2. run non-vital tests only once a while on a regular basis, e.g. lint tests
3. for major developers, I recommend to activate their Travis for the forked repo.
does this has relation to bn?

our baseline algorithm on cifar10 gets 90% test accuracy, see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification#cifar-10

so i think there should be room for improvement
Fix gamma means set gamma=1. This is the expected behavior.
Could you please rebase it so that I can merge in?
@winstywang @mli Sorry for disturbing you guys, I am busy with work these days, maybe can get an improved result this weekend.
I pushed this commit just for setting a checkpoint and will not push commits  until get a reasonable result.
I tried several samples in CUDA folder, it works well.

BTW, I used ldd to check dependencies in libmxnet.so, and pretty sure the required file is in right location.

me:~/mxnet/R-package/inst/libs$ ldd libmxnet.so | grep libcudart.so
    libcudart.so.7.5 => /usr/local/cuda-7.5/lib64/libcudart.so.7.5 (0x00007f53665e1000)

me:~/mxnet/R-package/inst/libs$ ls -l /usr/local/cuda-7.5/lib64/libcudart.so.7.5
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 19 Aug 15 23:55 /usr/local/cuda-7.5/lib64/libcudart.so.7.5 -> libcudart.so.7.5.18
@futurely  thx
不错的introduction
@mli  as well as cifar10 model

@tqchen and @thirdwing thank you very much. Sorry for my late replay. I have been very busy in the last two weeks. @thirdwing My code (not yet finished) is below, and no, I don't want something like slice_gates[1]. slice_gates[[1]] is more than appropriate. :) @dselivanov: I will certainly share code. But right now I'm very busy, so it will take some time to finish it. The code I've translated from python script so far is below. @thirdwing Here is my code I have writen so far. It's not finished yet, but I have meet another obstacle. When I try to use function mx.symbol.Group( ...) I've got the following error message: Returns error:Error in mx.symbol.Group(list_all) : # could not find function "mx.varg.symbo.internal.Group". The relevant part of code is ``` list_all = c(out_prob, unpack_c, unpack_h) list_all <- mx.symbol.Group(list_all) # Doesn't work: ????????????????? # Returns error:Error in mx.symbol.Group(list_all) : # could not find function "mx.varg.symbo.internal.Group" return(list_all) ``` (see a piece at the bottom of my code below): ``` library(mxnet) #--LSTMState LSTMState <- function(c,h){ state <- list(c = c, h = h) return(state) } #--LSTMParam LSTMParam <- function(i2h_weight, i2h_bias, h2h_weight, h2h_bias ){ param <- list(i2h_weight = i2h_weight, i2h_bias = i2h_bias, h2h_weight = h2h_weight, h2h_bias = h2h_bias) return(param) } #--LSTMModel LSTMModel <- function (rnn_exec, symbol, init_states, last_states, seq_data, seq_labels, seq_outputs, param_blocks){ param <- list(rnn_exec = rnn_exec, symbol = symbol, init_states = init_states, last_states = last_states, seq_data = seq_data, seq_labels = seq_labels, seq_outputs = seq_outputs, param_blocks = param_blocks) return(param) } #--LSTM Cell lstm <- function(indata, prev_state, param, num_hidden=512, seqidx, layeridx, dropout=0, name="lstm_cell"){ if(dropout > 0) indata <- mx.symbol.Dropout(data=indata, p=dropout) i2h <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=indata, weight=param$i2h_weight, bias=param$i2h_bias, num_hidden=4*num_hidden, name=paste0(name,"_t",seqidx ,"_l",layeridx, "_i2h")) h2h = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=prev_state$h, weight=param$h2h_weight, bias=param$h2h_bias, num_hidden=4*num_hidden, name=paste0(name,"_t",seqidx ,"_l",layeridx, "_h2h")) gates <- i2h + h2h in_gate <- mx.symbol.Activation(gates[[1]], act.type="sigmoid") in_transform <- mx.symbol.Activation(gates[[2]], act.type="tanh") forget_gate <- mx.symbol.Activation(gates[[3]], act.type="sigmoid") out_gate <- mx.symbol.Activation(gates[[4]], act.type="sigmoid") next_c <- (forget_gate * prev_state$c) + (in_gate * in_transform) next_h <- out_gate * mx.symbol.Activation(next_c, act.type="tanh") return(LSTMState(c=next_c , h= next_h)) } #-- Unroll LSTM network lstm_unroll <- function(num_lstm_layer, seq_len, input_size, num_hidden, num_embed, num_label, dropout=0, name){ # initialize the parameter symbols # placeholder nodes for all parameters embed_weight <- mx.symbol.Variable(paste0(name, "_embed_weight")) cls_weight <- mx.symbol.Variable(paste0(name, "_cls_weight")) cls_bias <- mx.symbol.Variable(paste0(name, "_cls_bias")) param_cells <- list() last_states <- list() for(i in 1: num_lstm_layer){ param_cells[[i]] <- list(NULL) last_states[[i]] <- list(NULL) param <- LSTMParam(i2h_weight = mx.symbol.Variable(paste0(name, "_l(",i,")_i2h_weight")), i2h_bias = mx.symbol.Variable(paste0(name, "_l(",i,")_i2h_bias")), h2h_weight = mx.symbol.Variable(paste0(name, "_l(",i,")_h2h_weight")), h2h_bias = mx.symbol.Variable(paste0(name, "_l(",i,")_h2h_bias"))) state <- LSTMState(c = mx.symbol.Variable(paste0(name, "_l(",i,")_init_c")), h = mx.symbol.Variable(paste0(name, "_l(",i,")_init_h"))) param_cells[[i]] <- param last_states[[i]] <- state } if(length(last_states) != num_lstm_layer){ stop("lstm_unroll: Number of LSTM layers != length of last states") } label = mx.symbol.Variable("label") # now unroll over time last_hidden = list() for (seqidx in 1:seq_len){ data <- mx.symbol.Variable(paste0(name,"_t" ,seqidx, "_data")) hidden <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=data, weight=embed_weight, num.hidden=num_embed, no.bias=TRUE, name=paste0(name, "_t", seqidx, "_embed")) # stack LSTM cells for(i in 1:num_lstm_layer){ dp <- ifelse( i == 1 , 0, dropout) # don't do dropout for data next_state <- lstm(num_hidden = num_hidden, indata = hidden, prev_state = last_states[[i]], param = param_cells[[i]], dropout=dp, seqidx =seqidx, layeridx = i, name=paste0(name, "_lstm_t",seqidx)) hidden <- next_state$h last_states[[i]] <- next_state } # decoder if(dropout > 0) hidden <- mx.symbol.Dropout(hidden, p=dropout) last_hidden <- c(last_hidden, hidden) } concat <- mx.symbol.Concat(num.args=2, last_hidden[[1]],last_hidden[[2]]) # It seem that something doesn't work properly, have to check fc <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=concat, weight=cls_weight, bias=cls_bias, num.hidden=num_label) sm <- mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data = fc, label = label, name=paste0(name, "_softmax")) out_prob <- c(sm) for(i in 1:num_lstm_layer){ state <- last_states[[i]] state <- LSTMState(c=mx.symbol.BlockGrad(data=state$c, name=paste0("l",i,"_last_c")), h=mx.symbol.BlockGrad(state$h, name=paste0("l",i,"_last_h"))) last_states[[i]] <- state } unpack_c <- c() unpack_h <- c() for(i in 1: length(last_states)){ unpack_c <- c(unpack_c, last_states[[i]]$c ) unpack_h <- c(unpack_h , last_states[[i]]$h) } list_all = c(out_prob, unpack_c, unpack_h) list_all <- mx.symbol.Group(list_all) # Doesn't work: ????????????????? # Returns error:Error in mx.symbol.Group(list_all) : # could not find function "mx.varg.symbo.internal.Group" return(list_all) } ```

Recently Baidu Silicon Valley AI Lab published their second generation of Deep Speech [1][2] which achieved 7x performance improvement than the first generation system.

[1] Dario Amodei, Rishita Anubhai, Eric Battenberg, Carl Case, Jared Casper, Bryan Catanzaro, Jingdong Chen, Mike Chrzanowski, Adam Coates, Greg Diamos, Erich Elsen, Jesse Engel, Linxi Fan, Christopher Fougner, Tony Han, Awni Hannun, Billy Jun, Patrick LeGresley, Libby Lin, Sharan Narang, Andrew Ng, Sherjil Ozair, Ryan Prenger, Jonathan Raiman, Sanjeev Satheesh, David Seetapun, Shubho Sengupta, Yi Wang, Zhiqian Wang, Chong Wang, Bo Xiao, Dani Yogatama, Jun Zhan, Zhenyao Zhu. [Deep Speech 2: End-to-End Speech Recognition in English and Mandarin](http://arxiv.org/abs/1512.02595). arXiv:1512.02595. 2015.
[2]   E. Elsen. Optimizing RNN performance. http://svail.github.io/rnn_perf. 2015.

try update to the newest code

so essentially nothing changed

I've instaled a new version and now it works fine. Thanks.
@tqchen @antinucleon Could you review this?
you need --recursive=true. and your images need to be organized into folders where each folder contains one and only one class. The default structure of imagenet dataset should be like this.
I'm guessing your opencv is not properly installed. Try setting USE_OPENCV to 0 in your osx.mk. If you want to use opencv, you need to install it with brew, or if that doesn't work, from source.

It is installed from brew, with the flag --with-contrib, could that be the issue? that this here causes the problem?

Do I understand it correctly that the mxnet build throws error expecting me to have Intel BLAS installed?

Okay thanks for spending your time on this. I figured it out, turned out to be very simple.
I put the contents of http://sourceforge.net/projects/opencvlibrary/files/3rdparty/ippicv/
into /usr/local/lib/

while i should have put it to /usr/local/ , letting what was in include/ and in lib/ fall into the right folder.
No problems after that.
Thanks
i think @antinucleon @winstywang @mavenlin are already on fixing the possible bug

You do need to use multiple GPU explicitly. Otherwise it will only use one gpu. try pass 

```
[mx.gpu(i) for i in range(4)]
```

instead for devices. However, we may not get significant speedup on MNIST, but will do on other dataset
loop in @pluskid for exact syntax in julia
Hat tip to tqchen, you helped me sir

@tqchen Thanks for the quick reply. 
That did the trick. As you pointed out the speed up was not that dramatic on MNIST (about 4s to 2.9s) but will likely be better for other larger datasets. 

For the lenet example, the complete syntax in Julia is:

```
model = mx.FeedForward(lenet, context=[mx.gpu(i) for i = 0:3])
```

**Note to Julia users:** The index for GPUs begins at **0** not **1**.
what's the network usage? you can check it by `nmon` if you are using linux

Ran some tests on cost vs. performance. About a x3.25 speedup which is quite good but it might be cheaper to run a few g2.2xlarge instead. Will try that next.
CIFAR-10 + MXNet.jl on #AWS
  g2.2xlarge = ~$0.07/h, 406s
  g2.8xlarge = ~$0.35/h,  126s
![cifar_10_using_1_gpu](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/831751/12005073/43626122-abd0-11e5-846d-a7a490d3aa3c.png)
![cifar_10_using_4_gpus](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/831751/12005074/454f6ed0-abd0-11e5-8f5f-712f113de6b3.png)
@mli  can you give me a few info about it?

- Yes, you need to construct GPU instances explicitly
- Yes, even in Julia, GPU counting starts with 0, as it corresponds to the native GPU ID, which starts with 0
- You could probably try to compare the CIFAR-10 speed here: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification#cifar-10 . Just FYI, I could not get as good performance with our K80 GPUs. That is probably because of some local misconfigurations or something. But I do observe almost linear speedup with multiple GPUs.
@shuokay no at all, many thanks for your contributions, we are just trying to help to improve the results
If it's buggy we probably shouldn't make it default for device?

This is a good idea. A few suggestions:
1) I also think travis is getting too slow. We should try to move as many things as possible out of it. 
2) How about regression-test instead of end-to-end test.
3) Can we also host models with the data service? People are having trouble downloading models as LFS runs out of quota.
4) I like the idea of versioned release. we can probably release them as branches so it's easier to make hot fixes after release.
Why should it be (800, 800)? I think (output_dim, input_dim) sounds right
We should test the performance impact before removing it. Is this an isolated bug or does it also happen on other cuda math functions?

We should not consider use kvstore abstraction for the nccl case.

Instead, try to expose an allreduce interface directly is more natural to the users in this case. Consider allreduce as another alternative BSP primitive, besides kvstore
Was due to incomplete installation of blas, consider change blas version to for example open blas, might be the quickest way to solve the issue
This can be solved by using the newest version of code, you might need to reinstall the package
There is CSVIterator, NumpyIterator for use.
Someone has done it, but is in Chinese: http://www.liuxiao.org/2015/12/ios-mxnet-%E7%9A%84-ios-%E7%89%88%E6%9C%AC%E7%BC%96%E8%AF%91/
@antinucleon Thank you very much! Could you tell me where I can find the usage of CSVIterator?

This is CSVIter example: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/kaggle-ndsb2
This is Numpy Iter example: https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/io.html#mxnet.io.NDArrayIter

After the training is done, there is some message wrong. What's the problem?

Thanks! I'll try again when I got a chance. I tend to believe it is our cluster's problem. I tried the python version of cifar 10  script by disabling the IO completely and was with no luck.

If someone can confirm that the case when the inferred shape is `()` is never valid, I can send a PR with one of the two fixes:
1. Make `infer_shape` return `None` if one of the shapes is `()`
2. Make `infer_shape` throw an exception if one of the shapes is `()`

unit and system (or end-to-end) are test levels, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_testing#Testing_levels while regression refers to the test types. so we probably use a fold called `system` since `end-to-end` means something else in deep learning.

the models are hosted on amazon s3 now, will move to the data service when it is ready

using branches for release may results a lot of branches on github. one often uses the tags for releasing,  see https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl/releases, but yes, it makes hotfix not so straightforward. @pluskid any ideas?

I would suggest using tags for releasing instead of branches. I think we can have major.minor.bugfix release versioning scheme and release more frequently when relatively major bugfixes are merged. I oppose using branches as releases because I feel it is very unmanageable if we want to back port bug fixes to every release branches. If there is no agreement on git workflows, we could probably try to follow some well established workflows such as [git flow](http://nvie.com/posts/a-successful-git-branching-model/) for a random example.

Travis CI could have [dedicated building servers](https://travis-ci.com/plans). The plan is quite expensive ($129/month). But github has an [education pack](https://education.github.com/pack), and private builds for Travis CI are available as long as you are a student. I have never tried to set that up. Maybe we could try to utilize that instead of setting up our own CI server (unless setting up is very easy and still integrate well with github).

In any case, I support splitting test cases into fast unit-test and deeper tests. I think it is a good idea to add coverage statistics. Currently MXNet.jl is using [codecov](https://codecov.io/github/dmlc/MXNet.jl?branch=master). I guess this might be a bit tricky as the main repo is actually a host of a lot of front-ends.

i tried codecov, unfortunately our python unittest's coverage is below 40%...

i'm trying to ensemble a build machine with two gpus, so we can do some easy end-to-end gpu tests for each push.

consider squash the changes into one as the others are abandoned.

http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/contribute.html#how-to-combine-multiple-commits-into-one
One thing we should do is to enable plugin as soon as possible in an formal way, so additional primitive, operator and loader, so these things can first start as an plugin
Thanks for the great job!
+1 for versioned release as @pluskid suggested, we might need a dedicated machine for the regression test.

Let us keep things in one repo, so contribution to the scala package also seen as major contribution to mxnet. We have done this for matlab, python and R and it works well so far.

@piiswrong The major problem on R tests is the cost to install R env, instead of running the test. For java and others, it is likely that we can do it in the docker images and things should be faster
@tqchen Just for my information, I can't seem to find where the the CI is done for Windows. Do you have another build server for that?
We don't yet have a CI for windows setup.
@tqchen I see, that's one of the major problems I'm having with JavaCPP. People who can't do builds by themselves are mostly the Windows users...

Sorry, I am not advocating to remove it, that is just one option.  It seems rather drastic.
I don't think any other functions are affected but I am not 100% sure.
Another option that could be taken would be to implement a version of pow that only accepts integers as exponent / automatically detects if there are integers in exponent and uses custom code.

@piiswrong @tqchen There are only a few R tests currently so it shouldn't take long for the unit tests to run. It only took several minutes to install those R dependencies and tools when I was setting it up long time ago but it looks like it's in a very different shape now. I will take a look to try to speed it up once we are done with the Scala package.

I ended up using
 caffe due to time limit and confusion about the layer defining in mxnet.

I think the reason to use exceptions is so that it can be caught by frontend (e.g. Python) instead of crashing in libmxnet. I would suggest using -DDMLC_LOG_FATAL_THROW=0 when debug=1. @tqchen @antinucleon
did you install cuda? Is it in LD_LIBRARY_PATH?

cuda is installed. 

export CUDA_HOME=/usr/local/cuda-7.5
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=${CUDA_HOME}/lib64 
PATH=${CUDA_HOME}/bin:${PATH} 
export PATH

is added in ~/.profile.

I have modify 
USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda-7.5 
ADD_CFLAGS =-I/usr/local/cuda-6.5/bin

as 

USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda 
ADD_CFLAGS =

now, it works。

thanks!
@shuokay In the paper, I don't see a relu before element-wise addition. But in your implementation, there is one. Did I misread that?

strange, (800, 200) should be i2h_weight shape.
I suggest you to do double checks.
agree with @piiswrong

Hi, @Lodewic 

Sorry about all the troubles. Compiling on Windows is a little annoying and I am afraid there is something you have to do manually. I list them blow:

(1) create the folder `R-package/inst/libs/x64`. We only support 64-bit operating system now, so you need `x64` foler;

(2) put dll files in `R-package/inst/libs/x64`;

(3) create the folder `R-package/inst/include` and copy all header files into it. Just like what we do in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/Makefile#L190-L192

(4) `R CMD INSTALL R-package`

BTW, you can find the pre-built package from [mxnet_0.5.zip](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dmlc/drat/gh-pages/bin/windows/contrib/3.2/mxnet_0.5.zip). You can unzip it and look throught it.
This seems to only save disk space as you have to decompress it to use. Probably of interesting to applications on mobile systems.
You can use concat layer to concatenate with a zero array
Basically we need to add -DDMLC_LOG_FATAL_THROW=0 when DEBUG=1 to CCFLAGS and NVCCFLAGS. @SkidanovAlex Would you like to contribute a PR?
I think this is caused by a missing CHECK on the C++ side. I would look into src/operator/softmax_output-inl.h:infer_shape. You are welcome to contribute a PR. Thanks!

We mostly focus on GPU performance so CPU is not optimized. But there is an easy fix that should improve performance a lot. check mshadow/tensor_cpu-inl.h:139. Currently the loop is not multithreaded. You can add multitheading with openmp on the outer loop. This should be easy and it should cover most ops. 
If you can make this work you are welcome to contribute a PR.
Thanks.
i'm afraid currently we don't have free hands to do it. please have a try if you are interested. it shouldn't be very hard. same comment to #1083

I built neural decision forests in Lasagne (https://github.com/SkidanovAlex/ShallowNeuralDecisionForest), where I actually managed to evaluate leaf probabilities in a vector form, allowing the entire model to be executed on a GPU. I was, however, never able to get as good results as theirs (it was on par with a regular NN on all the tasks I tried it, but was taking longer to converge). They never responded to my email to them with request for more details, so I don't know what exactly I am doing different.
We have concat and split layers. You can find the docs with `help(mxnet.sym)`
fixed in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1048
Thanks for the contribution!
@piiswrong , Thanks !
What is the format of your data? I think you can try NDArrayIter with http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.10.0/reference/generated/numpy.memmap.html
